text: <extra_id_0> Tumor necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA accumulation in human myelomonocytic cell lines .
Role of transcriptional regulation by DNA sequence motifs and mRNA stabilization .
The cytokine <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mediates many of the pathologic signs of cachexia , inflammation , and sepsis .
The current work describes the regulation of <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in human myelomonocytic cell lines after PMA stimulation .
The cell lines exhibit a low level of constitutive <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA expression .
Within 2 to 4 h of PMA exposure , steady state levels of <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA are markedly elevated in all myelomonocytic cell lines studied .
This rise is due to increased mRNA stability , which increased by almost twofold , and to an overall increase in transcription , which rises by more than sixfold .

At the level of the genomic <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene , a DNase I hypersensitive site is detected within the <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter between -200 to -100 bp relative to the transcription initiation site .
Although absent in nonexpressing erythroleukemia cell lines , the DNase I site is present in uninduced myelomonocytic cell lines and is not changed after PMA induction .

The PMA induction of <extra_id_0> c-fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA correlated well with <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene induction ; expression of genes encoding other proteins in the AP-1 complex ( <extra_id_0> junB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> junD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) were also induced by PMA .

The nuclear extracts from resting and induced ML-1 cells contain proteins binding specifically to the AP-1 , AP-2 , and NF kappa B sequence located within the <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .
PMA induction increases the level of a number of specific binding complexes relative to the resting cells .
The regulatory mechanisms of the human and murine <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> genes are discussed .
